meanings.definition: To bring under control or subjection.
meanings.sent1: The teacher needed to subduce the noisy classroom before starting the lesson.
meanings.sent2: The police officer had to subduce the suspect to prevent any further disturbance.
meanings.sent3: Trying to subduce a group of excited puppies is like herding cats.
meanings.sent4: Her determination to subduce her fear of public speaking was like taming a wild beast.
meanings.sent5: The superhero's ability to subduce villains with ease made him a formidable force for justice.

meanings.definition: To reduce the intensity or force of something.
meanings.sent1: Taking deep breaths can help subduce feelings of anxiety.
meanings.sent2: The medication was able to subduce the patient's severe pain.
meanings.sent3: Using humor to subduce tension in a room can be quite effective.
meanings.sent4: Her smile had the power to subduce even the strongest of storms.
meanings.sent5: The gentle music was able to subduce the baby's cries and lull it to sleep.

meanings.sent1: The army aimed to subduce the enemy forces and claim victory.
meanings.sent2: The king sought to subduce the neighboring kingdom and expand his empire.
meanings.sent3: The chef's secret ingredient was able to subduce even the pickiest eater.
meanings.sent4: Her unwavering determination helped her subduce all obstacles in her path.
meanings.sent5: The explorer's quest was to subduce the uncharted lands and make them his own.
